this is only an idea,  
myself never tried to make write protect my plain BartPE USB stick:  

try to pre create the fbwf.cfg not in the booted PE  
but in the real OS  
see [http://www.mp3car.co...ows-xp-pro.html](http://www.mp3car.com/vbulletin/winnt-based/121088-guide-using-fbwf-windows-xp-pro.html "External link"),  
then copy this .cfg to the USB root  
(do not forget to use 'fbwfmgr /enable', this enables FBWF upon restarting your computer)  

in the booted PE start the FBWF service manually  
and before start the FBWF service remove the '/MININT' switch  
(see [this post](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?s=&showtopic=5429&view=findpost&p=46400 "External link")):  
reg.exe ADD HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control /v SystemStartOptions /t REG_SZ /d "/FASTDETECT" /f  
net start fbwf

forumNotes.author: dera
forumNotes.content:
> Unfortunately renaming "minint" to "i386" wont help the FBWF-driver to start
No, the problem is not the folder name 'MININT' vs 'I386',  
but the '/MININT' switch in the registry key 'HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control' in the value 'SystemStartOptions'  
this prevent fbwf to read the .cfg file

> Ok, here's the next problem: > > FBWF automatically writeprotects hd0. > But on most systems hd0 is the internal hard-drive! > > Does anyone have an idea how to tell FBWF to protect the STICK? With the /MININT switch in the registry, the driver is instructed to read settings from registry, instead of cfg file and protect the systemdrive. It has worked flawlessly for me for CDVD, HDD, Flash Cards and even RAM-Drives. So i suspect, that it is the USB driver, which makes the trouble and causes the driver to pick the next drive, which uses the proper drivers, hd0.
